div1.p: Peabody seeks clarification of information for a pamphlet on yellow fever for the American Museum of Natural History.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Alvah H. Doty, September 9, 1928
div1.opener:
Can you give me any light on these pencilled questions?
(I found no reply to this in the Peabody Collection). JP
FROM JAMES E. PEABODY
September 9, 1928.
Dr. Alvah H. Doty,
Medical Director American Telegraph Western Union Co.,
195 Broadway, N. Y. City,
My dear Dr. Doty:
div1.p:
I understood you to say the other day when I talked with you that you
would be willing to put in writing the answers to several questions which
we discussed. I therefore beg leave to ask your further generous assistance
in the preparation of my pamphlet for the American Museum of Natural History
on the Conquest of Yellow Fever.

1. I have not the copy of the minutes of the hearing before th Committee
on Military Affairs of the House right here where I can refer to the text,
but I am sure I heard Col. Kean say at that time and in his office that far
too little credit has given to Dr. Agramonte in the government reports for
his work on the Yellow Fever Board. It is not too late for the Country to
learn the facts, and I am hoping you can secure a very specific statement
of our debt to this Cuban doctor. In your correction of my galley proofs
you changed my statement in regard to Dr. Agramonte (“who had recovered from
the disease and so was immune to further attacks”) to read “who was supposed
to be immune to the disease”. (I think after all this change was made by
Col. Kean). Does this mean that he had an attack in childhood which was so
light that it was not recognized? You told me that Dr. Agramonte sometimes
comes up from Cuba to your office. Would it be an imposition to ask if I
might meet him?

Can you give me Dr
Agramonte's service

2. I find in Dr. F. F. Russell's article in the Sigma Xi Quarterly,
March, 1925, on “War on Disease” the following statement which surprised me
much. (p.16) “It was probably the work of Doctor Henry R. Carter of the
United States Public Health Service rather than of Finlay which induced Reed
to change his plans.” Dr. H. A. Kelly in his “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
certainly gives a great deal of credit to Finlay for his theory. I cannot
find in the book a distinct statement that this Doctor conferred with Dr. Reed
but I am sure the statement is made in many places that Dr. Lazear secured
his Stegomyia mosquito eggs from Finlay. In “William Crawford Gorgas--His
Life and Work” by Mrs. Gorgas and Burton Hendrick the highest possible trib-
utes are given to Dr. Finlay. Among others--“Amost lovable man in character
and personality,” writes Gorgas; “no one could be thrown with Dr. Finlay daily
as I was for several years without becoming warmly attached to him and form-
ing the highest estimate of his scientific honesty and straightforwardness.”
On page 103 of the Gorgas book is the following: “There seems something like
the working of an intelligent fate in the fact that the three men--Carter,
Reed, and Gorgas--who seemed indispensable to solving the yellow-fever prob-
lem, were at work in Havana at the same time. Carter was there as Quarantine
Officer, and naturally he presented his tables to his fellow Virginian. Reed
gave them the most painstaking study. 'Are you sure your dates are accurate? 8
he asked Carter. Carter had no doubt on that point. 'Then,' said Reed, 'it
spells an insect host.'” Do you think I should omit all reference to Finlay
in view of these quotations? Will you give me the dates of your visits to
FROM JAMES E. PEABODY
(2).
Cuba? The date of Carter's paper, which Dr. Russell was kind enough to let
me read in typewritten form is June, 1901. Do you know of any earlier pa-
per? I shall try to get to the Academy of Medicine sometime this week, un-
less you can suggest a way to give full justice to both Finlay and Carter.
Is Carter still living?

I cannot find any
such paper at N. Y.
Academy of Med.

3. Another unfortunate misunderstanding seems to have arisen between the
supporters of Reed and Gorgas. When I was in Washinton in November, 1926,
I got the impression from at least two of the high government officials that
Mrs. Gorgas' Life of her husband failed to give due credit to Dr. Reed. In-
deed one of these men told me he tried his best to get Doubleday, Page and
Co. to change the original articles which I believe appeared in the WORLD'S
WORK before the chapters appeared in book form. I have read carefully the
chapter in Mrs. Gorgas' book on “Yellow Fever Meets its Master”, and I find
quotations like the following; “The story of the next few months has been
frequently told. It is the story of Reed and not the story of Gorgas. (p.
106). “He (Reed) had no sincerer mourner than Gorgas, who, for the rest of
his life never missed an opportunity to witness his debt to Reed. One day
General M. Weaver was walking down Connecticut Avenue, Washington, with his
little granddaughter. He met Gorgas then at the height of his fame. “Persis,
said the General to the little girl, 'this is General Gorgas, one of our
great men.' 'No, my child,' said Gorgas, in his soft accents, 'not a great
man; merely one who is trying to follow in the footsteps of a great man--
Walter Reed.'” What higher tributes could any writer put in any book--and
there are others in the Life of Gorgas. How extensive is the misunderstand-
ing? Surely there is honor enough for all those heroes, and we must not let
our young people know that there is a Sampson-Schley controversy in this
heroic story. Will you be good enough to read again my galleys so far as
they concern these two men, and let me know if I have been fair to both?

4. You, Dr. Russell, and I made a tentative annuity schedule for the sur-
vivors of those yellow fever experiments and for their widows--$5000 for
Mrs. Reed, $4000 for Dr. Agramonte, Mrs. Carroll, Mrs. Lazear, and for the
four Doctors who have recently died (or should the latters' survivors have
somewhat less?), and $2000 for each of the 18 privates who submitted to inoc-
ulation by mosquitoes or to the “fomites”. Do you still think this fair?
(Dr. F.F. Russell said, “You cannot suggest too high an annuity for Mrs. Reed, for
we are learning morse and more of his wonderful work. He was the genius
of the whole series of experiments, and his life was so valuable that the
military men in Cuba refused to allow him to submit his own body to the
mosquito tests.) It is fortunate that our bill did not pass at the last ses
sion, for it recommended a flat rate of $3000 for all. General Ireland was
absolutely right when he said that a higher annuity should be given to the
officers. I am exceedingly glad that Mrs. Gorgas' name was included in
the amended bill. What do you suggest for her? Col. Wainwright, who man-
aged that hearing with such skill, says he will be glad to talk with me nex
week, rand I should like to get your reaction before that time, if I am not
imposing on you with these many questions. You have information right from
the front line of battle; hence my boldness in appealing to you.

Should Dr Agramontes' name he
included? Well this mulbate against
Congressional action
